intro: Quercus graeca, commonly known as the Greek oak, is a deciduous tree native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in autumn. The tree produces acorns, which are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus graeca typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a slow growth rate. Its bark is rough and fissured, providing a distinctive appearance in both young and mature trees.
